IP2026032_syn_2:
REASON FOR PROCEDURE: [REDACTED], status post RUL BLVR, developed a significant right-sided pneumothorax with a persistent bronchopleural fistula despite thoracostomy drainage.
PROCEDURE NOTE: Under general anesthesia, the airway was re-accessed. The previously placed Zephyr valves in the RUL were id[REDACTED]. Given the clinical failure to resolve the pneumothorax, the decision was made to abort the volume reduction. All three valves were sequentially grasped and extracted utilizing valve retrieval forceps. Inspection of the bronchial mucosa revealed mild inflammatory changes but no trauma.
POST-PROCEDURE COURSE: The air leak volume diminished significantly following extraction. The patient was returned to the step-down unit for continued chest tube management.

IP2026032:
Interventional Pulmonology Procedure Note
Procedure: Flexible bronchoscopy with removal of endobronchial valves, right upper lobe, for post-BLVR pneumothorax.
Patient: [REDACTED], 70-year-old male with severe emphysema status post RUL BLVR 5 days prior.
Anesthesia: General anesthesia with endotracheal intubation (8.0 mm ETT).
Indication: Large right pneumothorax with persistent air leak and incomplete lung re-expansion despite chest tube drainage following recent RUL bronchial valve placement.
Background: The patient underwent RUL BLVR with three valves 5 days ago. On day 2 post-procedure, he developed a large right pneumothorax requiring chest tube placement. Despite appropriate chest tube position and suction, there was ongoing air leak and incomplete expansion of the RUL.
Procedure details: Under general anesthesia, a therapeutic bronchoscope was advanced through the ETT. The right bronchial tree was inspected. Three Zephyr valves were visualized in the RUL segmental bronchi with good seating. Given the persistent pneumothorax and continuous air leak, all three valves were removed sequentially using dedicated valve retrieval forceps. Each valve was grasped, collapsed, and withdrawn through the bronchoscope without difficulty. The underlying segmental bronchi were patent with mild mucosal edema but no active bleeding.
Complications: Mild oozing from one segmental takeoff controlled with topical epinephrine and cold saline. No immediate worsening of pneumothorax on post-procedure CXR; chest tube remained in place.
Disposition: Returned to step-down unit with chest tube on suction. Air leak decreased after valve removal.
Plan: Daily chest radiographs and monitoring of chest tube output and air leak. Consider chest tube removal once lung fully expanded and air leak resolves. No further BLVR planned on the right side.
